doc.field: Records of the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences Ultracomputer
Records of the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences Ultracomputer

The New York University Ultracomputer was developed in the 1980s at Computer Science department of the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences. Much of the original concept was developed by mathematician, computer scientist, and professor Jacob T. Schwartz. The Records of the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences Ultracomputer consist of schematics and logs of Ultracomputer II and Ultracomputer III from 1987.

Much of the original concept was developed by mathematician, computer scientist, and professor Jacob T. Schwartz. The Records of the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences Ultracomputer consist of schematics and logs of Ultracomputer II and Ultracomputer III from 1987.
The Records of the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences Ultracomputer consist of schematics and logs of Ultracomputer II and Ultracomputer III from 1987.

The New York University Ultracomputer was developed in the 1980s at Computer Science department of the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences. Much of the original concept was developed by mathematician, computer scientist, and professor Jacob T. Schwartz.

This collection was treated as an administrative transfer to the New York University Archives from the Courant Institute in the summer of 2023 when the Courant Institute Library closed. Original provenance is unknown. The accession number associated with this transfer is 2023.040.
